title: How to Choose Flowers for a Garden

steps.headline: Divide your garden area into sections according to the amount of sunlight they receive during the day.
steps.description: Use a can of white spray paint to mark off the areas, and observe them over a week to 10 days to make sure they are accurately marked. You will need this information when choosing garden flowers so that taller flowers do not cut off the sun from the lower growing plants.

steps.headline: Measure your garden area, overall and individual sections.
steps.description: Make a scale drawing of your garden, marking off the sections and indicating the sun density of each.

steps.headline: Browse your garden catalogs making notes of which flowers you are particularly attracted to and their light requirements.
steps.description: Check their space requirements and compare that with your scale drawing to see how many flowers you can fit in a plot.

steps.headline: Choose a garden color theme.
steps.description:
It can be as simple as choosing one or more colors and staying in those color families, or you can plan out a color riot with small patches of every color imaginable scattered around. One very pretty look is planting a color gradient by choosing one color, such as red. Plant the palest pink flowers in front and gradually darken the rows until you have deep red flowers, such as climbing roses, trained on trellises in the very back. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/cd\/Choose-Flowers-for-a-Garden-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Choose-Flowers-for-a-Garden-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"\/images\/thumb\/c\/cd\/Choose-Flowers-for-a-Garden-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/aid1508948-v4-728px-Choose-Flowers-for-a-Garden-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":"728","bigHeight":"546","licensing":"

steps.headline: Learn the planting zone you live in and buy flowers rated for that zone.
steps.description: Most every gardening catalog includes zone maps and appropriate growing zones for every plant they sell.

steps.headline: Group flowers according to their watering needs as much as possible.
Consider blooming times when planning your garden.
steps.description: Try to have a good mixture of blooming dates to ensure color all season long.

steps.headline: Consider flower use.
steps.description: Do you want a cutting garden to fill vases inside your home or maybe some lovely scented flowers to permeate the air? A cutting garden should have long stemmed flowers which will grow tall, so plan for that when plotting the flower garden. Scented flowers are nice beneath a window where their aroma can waft into your home.
